data.title: convert: HD 4.0 patch compatibility
data.body:
The HD Edition 4.0 patch changed a lot in data file storage. For example, DRS files are a thing of the past. The good part is that the new storage format is like, a million times better. The bad part is that the openage conversion script no longer works for up-to-date HD installations, and needs more special cases, probably.

I'll have time to work on this in a bit over a week, but if somebody else wants to pick it up in the mean time, feel free :smile:

data.title: Multithreaded convert
data.body:
Use '-j' option to 'media' command to specify amount of jobs to use.
Unfortunately, make cannot pass its own '-j' value.

Down to roughly 2m53s from 10m31s on 4-core (+HT) i7, with HDD.
Verified sha1sums for singlethreaded and multithreaded conversion the same.
Log on console can be out of order now.

data.body:
https://github.com/SFTtech/openage/blob/47294b90ee5410ff4e565edb22327155cf7eb02b/py/openage/convert/texture.py#L153

Implement efficient arrangement for all the textures grouped together on a big surface.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bin_packing_problem

data.title: Whitespace Style: Moving to Spaces for C++ indentation
data.body:
I'm sure you're all aware of openage's current C++ [whitespace style](https://github.com/SFTtech/openage/blob/master/doc/code_style/tabs_n_spaces.md), which involves using tabs for indentation, and spaces for alignment.

Unfortunately, due to the nature of C++, automatic checking is non-trivial, to say the least.

Almost all contributions - especially by new contributors - are plagued by whitespace issues.

For reviewers, it is annoying to manually check the style for every contribution, nag about and patiently wait for them to be fixed, but I imagine it is even more annoying for contributors who have to waste time on the ridiculous exercise of fixing them.

Switching over to a whitespace indentation style (namely: 4 spaces, similar to our PEP8 Python style) would remove many of the annoyances. A project-wide ban on tab characters could be enforced by the existing code compliance checker.

Tabs remain my personal favorite indentation style, but most editors and programmers seem to prefer indenting by spaces these days. Please share your opinions on the subject, so we may come to a satisfying solution.

If we decide to switch over to spaces, I'll implement the change in the near future. The commit would break almost all automatic merging, so I'll wait until most open pull requests have been merged.

data.title: Why not FIFE?
data.body:
I was reading around the nets and wondered why you don't use an existing 2D game engine like [FIFE](http://www.fifengine.net/). You could save a considerable amount of work for reinventing the wheel here and instead focus on actual game design.

Can anybody enlighten me about this decision?

data.title: Job test
data.body:
Hi guys !

I made another test but this time for the job manager subsystem. My test (compare_two_job_managers) gives to two different job managers (the first one with 1 worker and the second one with 4) a significant quantity of job functions, then they separately run one after the other to measure their execution time. In the end, I just compare the two execution times expecting that the first one is slower.

data.title: Made existing testcases test JobManager with atleast 10 jobs in parallel  #189
data.body:
Did the following things:
- `test_simple_jobs` tests the JobManager by giving it 10 jobs in parallel and checking if it succeeds.
- `test_simple_jobs_with_exception` tests by giving JobManager 5 normal jobs and 5 jobs with throw exceptions.

data.title: add test for log::FileSink
data.body:
I managed to test log messages through a FileSink: messages are written in /tmp/openage-log-test (maybe I should change that file name because there's already /tmp/openage-log and it can get ambiguous). So to see the messages you just need to read that file (cat /tmp/openage-log-test).

I set the FileSink's loglevel to err to ignore messages with a lower loglevel and it works fine.

data.title: Build failing in OSX 10.10.3 due to issue with thread_local declaration
data.body:
I did the usual `./configure --mode=debug --compiler=clang` and `make` where it crashes while building `thread_id.cpp`.

OSX version: `10.10.3`
Xcode version: `6.3`
Clang version:

```
Apple LLVM version 6.1.0 (clang-602.0.49) (based on LLVM 3.6.0svn)
Target: x86_64-apple-darwin14.3.0
Thread model: posix
```

Here's the error from `make`:

```
[ 31%] Building CXX object cpp/CMakeFiles/openage.dir/unit/unit.cpp.o
[ 32%] Building CXX object cpp/CMakeFiles/openage.dir/unit/unit_container.cpp.o
[ 33%] Building CXX object cpp/CMakeFiles/openage.dir/unit/unit_texture.cpp.o
[ 34%] Building CXX object cpp/CMakeFiles/openage.dir/unit/unit_type.cpp.o
[ 34%] Building CXX object cpp/CMakeFiles/openage.dir/util/thread_id.cpp.o
/Users/sreejith/Code/openage/cpp/util/thread_id.cpp:16:37: error: initializer for
      thread-local variable must be a constant expression
thread_local ThreadIdSupplier const current_thread_id
                                    ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
/Users/sreejith/Code/openage/cpp/util/thread_id.cpp:16:37: note: use 'thread_local' to
      allow this
/Users/sreejith/Code/openage/cpp/util/thread_id.cpp:16:54: error: expected ';' after top
      level declarator
thread_local ThreadIdSupplier const current_thread_id
                                                     ^
                                                     ;
2 errors generated.
make[3]: *** [cpp/CMakeFiles/openage.dir/util/thread_id.cpp.o] Error 1
make[2]: *** [cpp/CMakeFiles/openage.dir/all] Error 2
make[1]: *** [all] Error 2
make: *** [openage] Error 2
```

I read that this is a Mac bug with the new Xcode 6.3 update. Folks over at ROOT were having [similar issue](https://sft.its.cern.ch/jira/browse/ROOT-7267). Seems they've fixed it ([commit](https://github.com/root-mirror/root/commit/eb8b9597a14e1bf93e55aac73276db668020fe88#diff-7c21c65c67bbc341a44edb339bf9d01e)).

data.title: [WIP] Map Engine
data.body:
# Map Engine

moved map creation from the main loop to a new subsystem.
Created Interface for different map engines.
Implemented Engines:
- static: returns Grass map
- mandelbrot: returns Island of the shape of the mandelbrot set
- diamond square
- perline noise: true infinite random map possible

data.title: Fix annexed buildings
data.body:
Objects like the TC were not able to be built as the foundation got removed instantly (floating outlines for buildings get removed when a building begins construction, here the annex caused the TC to remove itself)

The TC has several stages wrt collisions, the floating stage causes no collisions, the construction stage allows no units on the foundation, and once completed construction parts of the tc are able to be walked over, this is now working.

Since the change to unique_ptr<TerrainObject> in Unit, the annex objects are not cleaned up (memleak), The solution is to allow TerrainObjects to also be owned by another TerrainObject, the make annex function is moved from Unit to TerrainObject. Deletion of the parent object will now cleanup all children.

data.title: Support for wrap-around maps
data.body:
In games where some teams start along along edge of the map, and some teams starting in the middle, I find that teams in the middle often get squeezed, as they are the closest opponent to all teams on the edges.

If the map wrapped around, so the opposite edges were linked, it would make for interesting, and perhaps more balanced play.

I realize that this is kind of counter to the idea of infinitely generating terrain, but as I imagine that a mode for set-size maps would make sense, in that context wrap-around maps could also be an idea.
## <bountysource-plugin>

data.title: openage is still not available for Apple Watch®!

Hello,

I recently bought an Apple Watch and I'm very disapointed to see that openage is not available for Apple Watch.
This is outrageous! I paid US$17k for this device and I can't play my favorite game on it.

This is very disapointing, considering the Apple Watch have a touch screen, I see no reason why no one have ported openage yet for it.

_This issue is, of course, a complete joke. I don't even own an Apple device. Keep up the good work guys._

data.title: visual fixes for dock/ships
data.body: fix for docks making ground invisible, and ships becoming invisible when moiving

data.title: Unit Attributes
data.body:
Units currently have attributes to hold all properties of a unit instance (current HP, max HP, Attacks, Garrison space, Building completion, resource content and many more) some attributes seem to be related to the type, and others seem tied to a specific unit instance.

To fix issues with unit attributes there needs to be a clear design, there are a few of ways I can think of:

1) Unit types have default attributes and these get copied to all new units, which allows any attribute to be modified at any time without affecting other units (allows engine to be used for other game designs other than aoc, but makes it hard for things like upgrading units)

2) Unit types hold all attributes and units have a minimal set of values like current HP. Easy to handle unit upgrades but could be difficult to extend and modify the game in future.

3) Unit types and Unit instances have the same attributes, looking up attributes on a unit first checks the instance, and if not there will check the Unit Type, This does the best of both since custom attributes are supported but not required.

data.title: Fixed keybind modifiers
data.body:
Keybinds (#284) were influenced by keys like caps lock and num lock, and stopped working if one of those keys was active. That's fixed now.

I've also moved the modifier stuff from `GameMain` to `KeybindManager`, to keep things organized.

data.title: Research in order for creating for buildings
Villager commands
data.body:
Adding functionality to villagers. Also fixing bugs while I find them.
## Implemented features:
- [x] Place a villager with the `v` key
- [x] Kill a selected unit with `delete`
- [x] Hide some UI elements when in `Actions mode`
- [x] Villagers can build some buildings with the `q`, `w`, `e` and `r` keys (with `control` key for military buildings)
- [x] Set current player with 1-8 keys, create units with correct color
- [x] You can select multiple of your own units or buildings, but only 1 enemy at a time
## Found/fixed bugs:
- [x] Most click commands should be on mouse-up, not mouse-down
- [x] Dead units can be selected
- [x] Villagers can build another player's buildings
- [x] Building preview image is always from player 1
- [ ] Some editor building previews are always in blue, regardless of the current player
- [x] Enemy units can be controlled
## Fixed by Jon0 in another branch:
- Villagers work in place when building can't be placed (something in the way)
- When building with multiple villagers, only one of them starts building, the others work in place
- Villager building animation sometimes is choppy/slow
- Deleting a building while it's being built sometimes crashes the game (or makes the building reappear)
- Villagers sometimes invisible while in attacking animation
## Won't fix bugs:

Small bugs that probably won't be fixed any time soon
- Game freezes a bit when moving units, especially when clicking outside of the map (pathfinding just slow?)
- Buildings can be placed on water (terrain doesn't have enough information for this yet, I think)

data.title: Gamedata sometimes not loading
data.body:
When loading the game for the first time since booting, the game data sometimes takes a long time to load.

I've had times where it loaded after a few minutes, and sometimes it didn't seem to load at all. And when it does load, it only takes like 5 seconds.

data.title: Issue 282: fixed argument parser
data.body:
- Fixed crashes for missing arguments
- Added shorthand `-v` for `--version`
- Added shorthand `-l` for `--list-tests`
- Added some comments for clarity

Fixes #282
